page.title: 04THE PILGRIM'S REST
page.content: The Pilgrim's Rest was built in the twelth century. It was originally a farmhouse with several acres of land. It was rebuilt in the fourteenth century on the old foundations, possibly due to earthquake damage in the thirteenth century. It was originally named Ye Olde Pilgrim's Rest'e but when George the second became king it became The Kings Head. Monks used to occupy the building and brewed their own cider. In 1975 the then owner changed the name back to The Pilgrim's Rest, as it stands on the Pilgrim's Way. It is said to have a ghost dating from the nineteenth century and the current owners, Mr. and Mrs. K. Lee have often felt a presence there. It is well known for its wide selection of real ales and is often used by modern day pilgrims.
